behavior_estimator.contextual_justification:
The boundary movement pattern shows a stable speed profile, gradual and consistent course change (COG shifting from ~58.9° to ~54.3°), and minimal heading fluctuation, all indicative of controlled navigation along a curved maritime route. The candidate movement vb_82841811344196675 matches this behavioral signature precisely: it describes a stable-speed trajectory with gradual course evolution along a gently curving path modeled by a second-order polynomial in latitude and longitude, consistent with the northeasterly curvature observed at the gap boundaries. Furthermore, its duration range (200~250) aligns well with typical segment lengths adjacent to the gap, and its intent—"following a curved maritime route"—directly mirrors the inferred navigational intent from the boundary data, ensuring continuity in both kinematic behavior and spatial progression.

explanation_composer.regulatory_rule_cue:
Traffic Separation Scheme (TSS) routing applicable in structured waterways; applies to cargo vessels navigating near designated shipping lanes
Operational Protocol Rationale: The vessel's behavior—maintaining stable speed, gradually adjusting course, and showing minimal heading variation—is typical when following a curved maritime route within a regulated traffic separation scheme. This pattern reflects adherence to predefined navigation channels designed to segregate opposing traffic flows and enhance safety in busy or geometrically constrained waterways. The consistent alignment between course over ground and heading, along with smooth trajectory curvature, indicates controlled autopilot-assisted transit rather than evasive maneuvers or free-hand navigation. This rules out alternative behaviors such as anchoring, maneuvering at random, or operating outside established routes, all of which would show greater speed variability, abrupt course changes, or significant heading deviations. The observed motion aligns with standard operating procedures for cargo vessels transiting curved segments of designated shipping lanes under normal sea conditions.
'''
